Eckhardt Filter

The Eckhardt digital filter is a widely used two-parameter method for separating base flow from total streamflow. Introduced by Eckhardt (2005), it improves upon one-parameter filters such as Lyne–Hollick by explicitly incorporating watershed characteristics through the maximum base-flow index (\(BFImax\)).

The Eckhardt filter is recursive and produces a base-flow time series that varies smoothly with discharge. The method is applied forward in time, and performance depends on the appropriate choice of its two parameters: the recession constant (\(\alpha\)) and the maximum base-flow index (\(BFImax\)).

The equation for the Eckhardt filter is as follows: \[ b_k = \frac{(1 - BFImax) \cdot \alpha \ b_{k-1} + (1 - \alpha) \cdot BFImax \ Q_k}{1 - \alpha \cdot BFImax} \]
where \(b\) is base flow, \(\alpha\) is the recession constant, \(BFImax\) is the maximum base-flow index, \(Q\) is the total streamflow, and \(k\) is the time step.

Parameters

Recession Constant (\(\alpha\))

The recession constant (\(\alpha\)) controls the rate at which base flow recedes over time. It typically ranges between 0.90 and 0.98, with higher values indicating slower recession rates.

A common approach to estimate \(\alpha\) is to analyze recession periods in the streamflow record. This can be done by identifying periods of declining discharge and fitting an exponential decay model to estimate the recession constant.

Maximum Base-Flow Index (\(BFImax\))

The maximum base-flow index (\(BFImax\)) represents the maximum proportion of total streamflow that can be attributed to base flow in a system.

Typical values, provided by Eckhardt (2005), are:

  • Perennial, porous aquifers: 0.80

  • Ephemeral, porous aquifers: 0.50

  • Perennial, hard-rock aquifers: 0.25

A robust approach to estimating \(BFImax\) is the backwards-filter method introduced by Collischonn and Fan (2013), which reconstructs a recession-controlled base-flow hydrograph by applying the filter in reverse and comparing base-flow volume to total volume.

Considerations

  • The Eckhardt filter is sensitive to the choice of both \(\alpha\) and \(BFImax\). It is recommended to test different values to find the most appropriate ones for a given dataset.
    • Commonly used values for \(\alpha\) are between 0.90 and 0.98, while \(BFImax\) values depend on watershed characteristics as outlined above.
  • The Eckhardt filter is best suited for continuous streamflow records and may not perform well with datasets that have significant gaps or irregular sampling intervals.
  • The Eckhardt filter is sensitive to the choice of both parameters— \(\alpha\) and \(BFImax\).
    • \(\alpha\) should be estimated from clean recession segments.
    • \(BFImax\) should reflect the long-term hydrologic character of the watershed rather than short-term variability.
  • \(BFImax\) values are not universal.
    • Highly permeable, perennial systems often justify \(BFImax\) in the range 0.80–0.95.
    • Flashy or steep systems may require values closer to 0.25–0.60.
    • The backwards-filter method of Collischonn and Fan (2013) provides a data-driven estimate of \(BFImax\), reducing reliance on subjective selection.

References

Collischonn, Walter, and Fernando Mainardi Fan. 2013. “Defining Parameters for Eckhardt’s Digital Baseflow Filter.” Hydrological Processes 27 (18): 2614–22. https://doi.org/10.1002/hyp.9391.
Eckhardt, K. 2005. “How to Construct Recursive Digital Filters for Baseflow Separation.” Hydrological Processes 19 (2): 507–15. https://doi.org/10.1002/hyp.5675.
